column1: # Separated Correlation Matrices for Cyber Risk Model (Unique NAICS Codes)
## 1. Correlation Matrix: Between Events
# Captures dependencies between cyber events based on shared attack vectors, vulnerabilities, and NAICS code overlap.

# Events: PHV.01 (Phishing-Enabled Breach), RN.01 (Ransomware), SC.01 (Supply Chain Compromise), CP.01 (Cyber-Physical Disruption), QC.01 (Quantum Computing Crypto Break), AI.01 (AI-Driven Deepfake Fraud), BE.01 (Data Breach).
# Format: (Lower Bound, Upper Bound)
## 2. Correlation Matrix: Between Services for the Same Event
# Captures dependencies between remedial services within a single event.
# Services: Forensics, Legal Support, Negotiation, Recovery.
# Format: (Lower Bound, Upper Bound)
# Note: Consistent across events due to similar service descriptions and uptake probabilities.
## 3. Correlation Matrix: Across NAICS Codes
# Captures dependencies for event-service pairs across unique NAICS codes.

# NAICS codes: 11 (Agriculture), 21 (Mining), 22 (Utilities), 23 (Construction), 31 (Food Manufacturing), 32 (Other Manufacturing), 33 (Other Manufacturing), 42 (Wholesale Trade), 44 (Retail Trade), 45 (Retail Trade), 48 (Transportation), 49 (Warehousing), 51 (Information), 52 (Finance and Insurance), 53 (Real Estate), 54 (Professional Services), 56 (Administrative Services), 61 (Educational Services), 62 (Health Care), 71 (Arts, Entertainment), 72 (Accommodation and Food Services), 81 (Other Services), 92 (Public Administration).
# Format: (Lower Bound, Upper Bound)
## 4. Correlation Matrix: Across Employee Sizes
# Captures dependencies for event-service pairs across employee size categories.
# Format: (Lower Bound, Upper Bound)
# Notes:
# - Ranges reflect uncertainty in attack co-occurrence, service dependencies, and industry/size risk profiles.
# - NAICS codes are unique, aggregating duplicates (e.g., multiple NAICS 31 entries) into a single risk profile per code.

# - Employee size correlations are higher for adjacent bands (e.g., 10–14 vs. 15–19: 0.6–0.8) due to similar IT setups, lower for distant bands (e.g., <5 vs. 5,000+: 0.1–0.3) due to differing attack surfaces.
# - Use these matrices in an Excel-based Monte Carlo simulation or copula model to estimate pure premium by NAICS and employee size.
# - For Excel output, store matrices in a separate worksheet and use VLOOKUP/INDEX-MATCH to apply correlations in pure premium calculations for each deductible-limit tab.
# - Adjust ranges with specific threat intelligence or historical incident data if available.
